body_html:
When I run

git describe

I get

fatal: Not a git repository (or any parent up to mount point /home)
Stopping at filesystem boundary (GIT_DISCOVERY_ACROSS_FILESYSTEM not set).

So I must have done something wrong. What exactly do you mean by "from the root of your tensorflow sources"?
Does that simply mean to call

cd /home/bonkoodle/tensorflow

so that I'm in my tensorflow folder before running it? Or is there something more complex I have to do?
I feel like most things aren't explained clearly enough for a beginner like me. It's just assumed that I know loads of stuff.

But if I call

source ./tensorflow/bin/activate

then I can successfully run the standard test code of:

python

import tensorflow as tf
hello = tf.constant('Hello, TensorFlow!')
sess = tf.Session()
print(sess.run(hello))

I tried installing it on my laptop but encountered the exact same error.
Both times my tensorflow folder was missing the examples folder and didn't have the BUILD file or tensorflow.bzl.
So what I did was to download the whole tensorflow-master from https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow
Then copy the files over to my regular tensorflow installation.
But that's quite likely why it's not working, I must have done something incorrectly, is there some other way of adding these additional folders/files which are needed for running "bazel build tensorflow/examples/image_retraining:retrain"?

Also should I be using Python 2.7 or Python 3.x?
I'm attempting with 2.7 atm but not really sure which is best.

As for installing from source I gave it a go and so far got down to the line where you call

sudo pip install /tmp/tensorflow_pkg/tensorflow-1.0.1-py2-none-any.whl

but I'm getting an error

IOError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: '/tmp/tensorflow_pkg/tensorflow-1.0.1-py2-none-any.whl'

Isn't that the name of the file which we're trying to install though? So why would it be looking for the file it's installing?

When I run

git describe

I get

fatal: Not a git repository (or any parent up to mount point /home)
Stopping at filesystem boundary (GIT_DISCOVERY_ACROSS_FILESYSTEM not set).

So I must have done something wrong. What exactly do you mean by "from the root of your tensorflow sources"?
Does that simply mean to call

cd /home/bonkoodle/tensorflow

so that I'm in my tensorflow folder before running it? Or is there something more complex I have to do?
I feel like most things aren't explained clearly enough for a beginner like me. It's just assumed that I know loads of stuff.
But if I call

source ./tensorflow/bin/activate

then I can successfully run the standard test code of:

python


import tensorflow as tf
hello = tf.constant('Hello, TensorFlow!')
sess = tf.Session()
print(sess.run(hello))



I tried installing it on my laptop but encountered the exact same error.
Both times my tensorflow folder was missing the examples folder and didn't have the BUILD file or tensorflow.bzl.
So what I did was to download the whole tensorflow-master from https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow
Then copy the files over to my regular tensorflow installation.
But that's quite likely why it's not working, I must have done something incorrectly, is there some other way of adding these additional folders/files which are needed for running "bazel build tensorflow/examples/image_retraining:retrain"?
Also should I be using Python 2.7 or Python 3.x?
I'm attempting with 2.7 atm but not really sure which is best.
As for installing from source I gave it a go and so far got down to the line where you call

sudo pip install /tmp/tensorflow_pkg/tensorflow-1.0.1-py2-none-any.whl

but I'm getting an error

IOError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: '/tmp/tensorflow_pkg/tensorflow-1.0.1-py2-none-any.whl'

Isn't that the name of the file which we're trying to install though? So why would it be looking for the file it's installing?
body:
When I run 
> git describe

I get 
> fatal: Not a git repository (or any parent up to mount point /home)
Stopping at filesystem boundary (GIT_DISCOVERY_ACROSS_FILESYSTEM not set).

So I must have done something wrong. What exactly do you mean by "from the root of your tensorflow sources"? 
Does that simply mean to call 
> cd /home/bonkoodle/tensorflow

so that I'm in my tensorflow folder before running it? Or is there something more complex I have to do?
I feel like most things aren't explained clearly enough for a beginner like me. It's just assumed that I know loads of stuff.

But if I call 
> source ./tensorflow/bin/activate

then I can successfully run the standard test code of: 
> python 
>>> import tensorflow as tf
>>> hello = tf.constant('Hello, TensorFlow!')
>>> sess = tf.Session()
>>> print(sess.run(hello))

I tried installing it on my laptop but encountered the exact same error.
Both times my tensorflow folder was missing the examples folder and didn't have the BUILD file or tensorflow.bzl.
So what I did was to download the whole tensorflow-master from https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow
Then copy the files over to my regular tensorflow installation.
But that's quite likely why it's not working, I must have done something incorrectly, is there some other way of adding these additional folders/files which are needed for running "bazel build tensorflow/examples/image_retraining:retrain"?

Also should I be using Python 2.7 or Python 3.x?
I'm attempting with 2.7 atm but not really sure which is best.


As for installing from source I gave it a go and so far got down to the line where you call
> sudo pip install /tmp/tensorflow_pkg/tensorflow-1.0.1-py2-none-any.whl

 but I'm getting an error 
> IOError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: '/tmp/tensorflow_pkg/tensorflow-1.0.1-py2-none-any.whl'

Isn't that the name of the file which we're trying to install though? So why would it be looking for the file it's installing?
